where $\hat\lambda= \langle\lambda\rangle_{b(\lambda)}$.

Since for the observation nodes $m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}\to h_{j}}(h_j)$, $\text{for}\ j\in {\mathcal{P}}$ the value of $x_j$ be known for the receiver, so the message $m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}\to h_{j}}(h_j)$, is calculated by

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle{m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}\to{h_{i}}}(h_{i})}" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>D</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\exp\left\{\langle{\log f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}(h_{i},x_{i},\lambda%
)}\rangle_{b(x_{i})b(\lambda)}\right\}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>D</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\propto{{\mathcal{CN}}\left(h_{i};\frac{y_{i}\langle x_{i}\rangle%
_{b(x_{i})}}{\left\langle|x_{i}|^{2}\right\rangle_{b(x_{i})}},\frac{1}{\hat{%
\lambda}\left\langle|x_{i}|^{2}\right\rangle_{b(x_{i})}}\right)}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒞</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒩</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>;</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow><msub><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle><mo>,</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\triangleq{{\mathcal{CN}}\left(h_{i};{\hat{\theta}_{i}},{\nu_{%
\theta_{i}}}\right)}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>≜</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒞</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒩</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>;</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
For the convenience of description, the messages ${m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_j}\to{h_j}}(h_j)}, \forall j\in {\mathcal{P}}$ and $m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}\to h_{i}}(h_i), \forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}$ uniformly denoted as ${m_{f_{{\mathrm{y}}_i}\to{h_i}}(h_i)}, \forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}\cup{\mathcal{P}}$.
\subsubsection{Messages in dense-edge-connection part}\
For the first iteration, we initiate the messages  $f_{\delta_i\to h_i}(h_i)$, $\forall i\in{\mathcal{D}}\cup{\mathcal{P}}$ as
$m_{f_{\delta_i}\to h_i}(h_i)={\mathcal{CN}}(h_i;\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i})$,
later update it in \eqref{eq:msg_xi}.
The beliefs $b(\alpha_l)$ of time-domain channel taps $\alpha_l, \forall l\in [1:L]$ are initiated as
$b(\alpha_l)\triangleq{\mathcal{CN}}(\alpha_l;\hat\alpha_l,\nu_{\alpha_l})$, which will be updated by \eqref{eq:blf_alpha}.

For the clarity of presentation, we fragment the calculation of messages into following 5 steps.

\textbf{Step1:} Using \cite[Eq. (35)]{Rangan2010}, the belief $b(h_i)$ of each  frequency-domain channel weight $h_i$ can be calculated as\footnote{From the probabilistic understanding of message passing, the message $m_{f_{y_i}\to h_i}(h_i)\propto {\mathcal{CN}}(h_i;\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})$  approximates to the likelihood function $p({\boldsymbol{y}}|h_i)$, which is used to define function $f_{{\mathrm{out}}}$ in \cite[Eq. (15a)]{Rangan2010}. Therefore, we can re-denote function $F_{{\mathrm{out}}}$ in \cite[Eq. (26)]{Rangan2010}  as
$F_{{\mathrm{out}}}(h_i,\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i},\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})\triangleq
\log {m_{f_{{\mathrm{y}}_i}\to{h_i}}(h_i)}-\frac{1}{2\nu_{\xi_i}}|h_i-\hat\xi_i|^2$, which is equivalent to the  belief  $b(h_i)$ in log-domain.}
\begin{eqnarray}
b(h_i)&\propto&\exp \left\lbrace F_{{\mathrm{out}}}(h_i,\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i},\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})\right\rbrace \nonumber\\
&\propto& {m_{f_{{\mathrm{y}}_i}\to{h_i}}(h_i)}{m_{f_{\delta_i}\to h_i}(h_i)}\nonumber\\
&\propto& {\mathcal{CN}}(h_i;\hat{h}_i,\nu_{h_i}),
\end{eqnarray}

where
\begin{eqnarray}
\nu_{h_i}=\left({\frac{1}{\nu_{\theta_i}}+\frac{1}{\nu_{\xi_i}}}\right)^{-1}\label{eq:blf_h_v};~~~
\hat{h}_i=\nu_{h_i}\left({\frac{\hat{\theta}_i}{\nu_{\theta_i}}+\frac{\hat\xi_i}{\nu_{\xi_i}}}\right)
\label{eq:blf_h_m}\nonumber.
\end{eqnarray}

\textbf{Step2:} Compute the two intermediate parameters $s_i$ and $\tau_{s_i}$ for each $i$ by using \cite[Eqs. (6a), (6b), (36)  and (37)]{Rangan2010}\footnote{Similar to $F_{{\mathrm{out}}}$, we also denote $g_{{\mathrm{out}}}$, defined in \cite[Eq. (36)]{Rangan2010},  by $g_{\mathrm{out}}(\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i},\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})$.}
prevtext:
where $\hat\lambda= \langle\lambda\rangle_{b(\lambda)}$.

Since for the observation nodes $m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}\to h_{j}}(h_j)$, $\text{for}\ j\in {\mathcal{P}}$ the value of $x_j$ be known for the receiver, so the message $m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}\to h_{j}}(h_j)$, is calculated by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}\to h_{j}}(h_{j})" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>j</mi></msub></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\exp\left\{\langle{\log f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}(h_{j},\lambda)}%
\rangle_{b(\lambda)}\right\}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>j</mi></msub></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\propto{{\mathcal{CN}}\left(h_{j};\frac{y_{j}}{x_{j}},\frac{1}{%
\hat{\lambda}{|x_{j}|^{2}}}\right)}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒞</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒩</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>;</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mfrac></mstyle><mo>,</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\triangleq{\mathcal{CN}}(h_{j};\hat{\theta}_{j},\nu_{\theta_{j}})." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>≜</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒞</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒩</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>;</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
For the convenience of description, the messages ${m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_j}\to{h_j}}(h_j)}, \forall j\in {\mathcal{P}}$ and $m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}\to h_{i}}(h_i), \forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}$ uniformly denoted as ${m_{f_{{\mathrm{y}}_i}\to{h_i}}(h_i)}, \forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}\cup{\mathcal{P}}$.
\subsubsection{Messages in dense-edge-connection part}\
For the first iteration, we initiate the messages  $f_{\delta_i\to h_i}(h_i)$, $\forall i\in{\mathcal{D}}\cup{\mathcal{P}}$ as
$m_{f_{\delta_i}\to h_i}(h_i)={\mathcal{CN}}(h_i;\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i})$,
later update it in \eqref{eq:msg_xi}.
The beliefs $b(\alpha_l)$ of time-domain channel taps $\alpha_l, \forall l\in [1:L]$ are initiated as
$b(\alpha_l)\triangleq{\mathcal{CN}}(\alpha_l;\hat\alpha_l,\nu_{\alpha_l})$, which will be updated by \eqref{eq:blf_alpha}.

For the clarity of presentation, we fragment the calculation of messages into following 5 steps.

\textbf{Step1:} Using \cite[Eq. (35)]{Rangan2010}, the belief $b(h_i)$ of each  frequency-domain channel weight $h_i$ can be calculated as\footnote{From the probabilistic understanding of message passing, the message $m_{f_{y_i}\to h_i}(h_i)\propto {\mathcal{CN}}(h_i;\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})$  approximates to the likelihood function $p({\boldsymbol{y}}|h_i)$, which is used to define function $f_{{\mathrm{out}}}$ in \cite[Eq. (15a)]{Rangan2010}. Therefore, we can re-denote function $F_{{\mathrm{out}}}$ in \cite[Eq. (26)]{Rangan2010}  as
$F_{{\mathrm{out}}}(h_i,\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i},\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})\triangleq
\log {m_{f_{{\mathrm{y}}_i}\to{h_i}}(h_i)}-\frac{1}{2\nu_{\xi_i}}|h_i-\hat\xi_i|^2$, which is equivalent to the  belief  $b(h_i)$ in log-domain.}
\begin{eqnarray}
b(h_i)&\propto&\exp \left\lbrace F_{{\mathrm{out}}}(h_i,\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i},\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})\right\rbrace \nonumber\\
&\propto& {m_{f_{{\mathrm{y}}_i}\to{h_i}}(h_i)}{m_{f_{\delta_i}\to h_i}(h_i)}\nonumber\\
&\propto& {\mathcal{CN}}(h_i;\hat{h}_i,\nu_{h_i}),
\end{eqnarray}

where
\begin{eqnarray}
\nu_{h_i}=\left({\frac{1}{\nu_{\theta_i}}+\frac{1}{\nu_{\xi_i}}}\right)^{-1}\label{eq:blf_h_v};~~~
\hat{h}_i=\nu_{h_i}\left({\frac{\hat{\theta}_i}{\nu_{\theta_i}}+\frac{\hat\xi_i}{\nu_{\xi_i}}}\right)
\label{eq:blf_h_m}\nonumber.
\end{eqnarray}

\textbf{Step2:} Compute the two intermediate parameters $s_i$ and $\tau_{s_i}$ for each $i$ by using \cite[Eqs. (6a), (6b), (36)  and (37)]{Rangan2010}\footnote{Similar to $F_{{\mathrm{out}}}$, we also denote $g_{{\mathrm{out}}}$, defined in \cite[Eq. (36)]{Rangan2010},  by $g_{\mathrm{out}}(\hat\xi_i,\nu_{\xi_i},\hat\theta_i,\nu_{\theta_i})$.}

nexttext: Analogously,  the message $m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_i} \to \lambda}(\lambda)$ from data observation node $f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}$ to $\lambda$, $\forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}$, yields as followed,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle m_{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}\to\lambda}(\lambda)" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>j</mi></msub></msub><mo>→</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex8.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\exp\left\{{\langle{f_{{\textrm{P}}_{j}}(h_{j},\lambda)}\rangle_%
{b(h_{j})}}\right\}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mi>j</mi></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\propto{\lambda{\exp\left\{-\lambda{\langle|y_{j}-{x_{j}}{h_{j}}|%
^{2}\rangle}_{b(h_{j})}\right\}}}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Analogously,  the message $m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_i} \to \lambda}(\lambda)$ from data observation node $f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}$ to $\lambda$, $\forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}$, yields as followed,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}\to\lambda}(\lambda)" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>D</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>→</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex9.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\exp\left\{{\langle{f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}(h_{i},\lambda)}\rangle_%
{b(h_{i})b(x_{i})}}\right\}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>D</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\propto{\lambda{\exp\left\{-\lambda{\langle|y_{i}-{x_{i}}{h_{i}}|%
^{2}\rangle}_{b(h_{i})b(x_{i})}\right\}}}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\subsection{Soft Demodulation and Decoding}
The message $m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}\to x_i}(x_i)$  from data observation node $f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}$ to variable node $x_i$, $\forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}$, is computed by using MF rule,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\hat{\lambda}=\frac{P+N}{\sum\limits_{j\in{\mathcal{P}}}{\langle{%
|y_{j}-{x_{j}}{h_{j}}|^{2}}\rangle_{b(h_{j})}}+\sum\limits_{i\in{\mathcal{D}}}%
\langle|y_{i}-{x_{i}}{h_{i}}|^{2}\rangle_{b(h_{i})b(x_{i})}}." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒫</mi></mrow></munder><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒟</mi></mrow></munder><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Massages $\{n_{x_i\to{f_{{\textrm{M}}}}}(x_i)=m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}\to{x_i}}(x_i),\ \text{for all } i\in{\mathcal{D}}\} $ are passed to soft demodulation and decoding models, where demodulation is performed by standard BP message update rule and  decoding  uses the forward-backward (BCJR) algorithm~\cite{Kschischang2001}. Then the discrete extrinsic messages $n_{x_i\to{f_{{\textrm{M}}}}}(x_i)= \sum_{s\in \mathcal{S}}\beta_i(s)\delta(x_i-s) $ are passed back, where $\mathcal{S}$ stands for modulation constellation. At last, the belief $b(x_i)$ of data symbol $x_i$, $\forall i\in{\mathcal{D}}$ is updated by
prevtext:
\subsection{Soft Demodulation and Decoding}
The message $m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}\to x_i}(x_i)$  from data observation node $f_{{\textrm{D}}_i}$ to variable node $x_i$, $\forall i\in {\mathcal{D}}$, is computed by using MF rule,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle m_{f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}\to{x_{i}}}(x_{i})" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>D</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex10.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\exp\left\{\left\langle\log f_{{\textrm{D}}_{i}}(h_{i},x_{i},%
\lambda)\right\rangle_{b(h_{i})b(\lambda)}\right\}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>exp</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><msub><mrow><mo>⟨</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mtext>D</mtext><mi>i</mi></msub></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>}</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\propto{{\mathcal{CN}}\left(x_{i};\frac{y_{i}{\hat{h}_{i}}}{{\nu_%
{h_{i}}}+{|\hat{h}_{i}|^{2}}},\frac{1}{\hat{\lambda}({\nu_{h_{i}}}+{|\hat{h}_{%
i}|^{2}})}\right)}" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>∝</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒞</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒩</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>;</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>,</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></msub><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\subsection{Computational complexity analysis}
The  dissimilarity  between  proposed algorithm and that in \cite{Badiu2012} is the  message computations in channel estimation, so we only compare the complexity of channel estimation. In \cite{Badiu2012}, it needs inversion operation of a large matrix with dimension $N\times N$ in each iteration, so the complexity is proportional to $\mathcal{O}(N^3)$, while the proposed algorithm avoids inversion operation of matrices and its complexity is proportional to $\mathcal{O}(NL)$, since it is derived on a well-factorized graph. More ever, since our algorithm can be compute in parallel schedule, the fast Fourier transformation (FFT) could be used, in this sense the computational complexity could reduce to $\mathcal{O}(N\log N)$.
\section{Simulation Result}\label{Sec:sim}
We considered an OFDM system with parameters given in Table~\ref{tab:para}, and we compare our proposed algorithm and the state-of-art in literatures, by means of Monte-Carlo simulations in terms of BER performance, which we label as follows. ``LC-BP-MF'' denote our proposed low complexity BP-MF based algorithm. The ``BP-MF-Freq.'' and ``LC-BP-EP'' stand for the algorithms introduced in~\cite{Badiu2012} and~\cite{Schniter2011}. To include an ideal reference, a receiver which has perfect channel state information (CSI) is also assessed, labeled as ``Perfect CSI''. The message-passing schedule planed as follow, firstly we estimate the time domain channel taps only use the pilots by 5 times of iteration, secondly use the estimated channel taps to execute soft detection and then use the detected symbols to estimate channel again iteratively.

In Fig.~\ref{fig:Ber}, the BER performance of the receivers is shown versus SNR (in dB), values, with all receivers running in 15 iterations of their respective algorithms. We observed from this figure that the three algorithms perform exactly the same and approaching the performance of ``Perfect CSI''. It is noteworthy that the variance of AWGN is given when simulate the ``BP-EP'' based receiver, while the ``LC-BP-MF'' and ``BP-MF-Freq.'' is unknown and be estimated in iteration.

Fig.~\ref{fig:Iter} depicted the BER of the receivers operating at a SNR
of 10dB and 8dB as a function of the iteration index. It shows that, the proposed ``BP-MF-LC'' receiver has a notable faster convergent rate than the ``BP-EP'', while converge slightly slower than the ``BP-MF-Freq.'' based receiver. This result is somewhat conflict with the results presented in \cite{Wu2014}, this may because MF rule have a slower convergence rate in long code word condition. But after convergent, the there algorithms have almost the same BER performance.

\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.4\textwidth]{BERvsSNR.pdf}
\caption{BER performance of the considered receivers versus SNR.}
\label{fig:Ber}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[!t]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=0.4\textwidth]{BERvsIter.pdf}
\caption{BER performance of the considered receivers versus iteration index
for an SNR of 8 dB.}
\label{fig:Iter}
\end{figure}

\section{Conclusion}
An low complexity iterative receiver jointly performing channel estimation, noise precision estimation and decoding is proposed based on combined BP-MF message passing framework for OFDM systems. By translate the channel estimation into time-domain and the stretch of factor graph, firstly we exploit the GAMP algorithm into the dense connection achieve the low computational complexity. Secondly, exploit MF update rule to the observation nodes, realize the estimation of noise precision. The numerical results show that the proposed LC-BP-MF receiver have the same BER performance with BP-MF-Freq. while have extremely low complexity.
